elements.content: Gas sorption experiments and grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations for two isostructural microporous metal azolate frameworks show that even partially exposed uncoordinated nitrogens can effectively increase gas binding affinity and overcome the pore size confinement effect.
elements.clean_text: Gas sorption experiments and grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations for two isostructural microporous metal azolate frameworks show that even partially exposed uncoordinated nitrogens can effectively increase gas binding affinity and overcome the pore size confinement effect.

elements.content: Porous coordination polymers (PCPs) have been of great interest for potential applications in gas storage and separation. It is well-known that large total pore volume is crucial for high gas uptake capacity, but small pore size elevates host−guest interactions and sorption amount at low relative pressures and/or high temperatures. As total pore volume is determined by (usually proportional to) pore size, volume-size optimization can have a limited effect. Alternatively, adsorption enthalpy may be enhanced by pore surface active sites such as coordinatively unsaturated metal centers and amine groups, which have been regarded to be useful for CO2 and/or H2. Nevertheless, there are rare reports that have unambiguously proven the roles of active sites, especially for organic functional groups, since pore surface engineering usually changes not only surface property but also pore volume, pore size, and even whole framework structure. In this context, evaluation of weaker or nonclassical active sites is more challenging and intriguing.
elements.clean_text: Porous coordination polymers (PCPs) have been of great interest for potential applications in gas storage and separation. It is well-known that large total pore volume is crucial for high gas uptake capacity, but small pore size elevates host-guest interactions and sorption amount at low relative pressures and/or high temperatures. As total pore volume is determined by (usually proportional to) pore size, volume-size optimization can have a limited effect. Alternatively, adsorption enthalpy may be enhanced by pore surface active sites such as coordinatively unsaturated metal centers and amine groups, which have been regarded to be useful for CO2 and/or H2. Nevertheless, there are rare reports that have unambiguously proven the roles of active sites, especially for organic functional groups, since pore surface engineering usually changes not only surface property but also pore volume, pore size, and even whole framework structure. In this context, evaluation of weaker or nonclassical active sites is more challenging and intriguing.

elements.content: Our previous studies have demonstrated that metal azolate frameworks (MAFs) are favorable for controlling framework and pore surface structures. The azolate nitrogen donors can be presicely controlled as coordination and guest binding sites. Nevertheless, the roles of nitrogen donors in the resultant PCPs are not always straightforward. For example, crystallographic studies for the porous cuprous 3,5-diethyl-1,2,4-triazolate (MAF-2) loaded with different gases suggested that the coordinated nitrogens behave as the primary sorption sites, but detailed energy profiles are still unavailable without comparison with highly related materials. Another type of puzzle is represented by a newly synthesized porous MAF [Co(dpt24)2] (1, MAF-25, dpt24 = 3-(2-pyridyl)-5-(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate), in which the uncoordinated nitrogens are only partially exposed on the pore surface. To evaluate the activity of these nitrogens, we constructed an isostructural porous MAF [Co(mdpt24)2] (2, MAF-26, mdpt24 = 3-(3-methyl-2-pyridyl)-5-(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate) for comparison. The methyl substituted new ligand was designed to block the suspected uncoordinated nitrogens.
elements.clean_text: Our previous studies have demonstrated that metal azolate frameworks (MAFs) are favorable for controlling framework and pore surface structures. The azolate nitrogen donors can be presicely controlled as coordination and guest binding sites. Nevertheless, the roles of nitrogen donors in the resultant PCPs are not always straightforward. For example, crystallographic studies for the porous cuprous 3,5-diethyl-1,2,4-triazolate (MAF-2) loaded with different gases suggested that the coordinated nitrogens behave as the primary sorption sites, but detailed energy profiles are still unavailable without comparison with highly related materials. Another type of puzzle is represented by a newly synthesized porous MAF [Co(dpt24)2] (1, MAF-25, dpt24 = 3-(2-pyridyl)-5-(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate), in which the uncoordinated nitrogens are only partially exposed on the pore surface. To evaluate the activity of these nitrogens, we constructed an isostructural porous MAF [Co(mdpt24)2] (2, MAF-26, mdpt24 = 3-(3-methyl-2-pyridyl)-5-(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate) for comparison. The methyl substituted new ligand was designed to block the suspected uncoordinated nitrogens.

elements.content: The isostructural compounds crystallize in the trigonal space group R3̅. Each octahedrally coordinated CoII ion is chelated by the 2-pyridyl and triazolate 2-nitrogens from two ligands in the trans configuration, and the two remaining coordination sites are occupied by 4-pyridyl nitrogens from adjacent units (Figure S1, ), giving rise to a 4-connected three-dimensional (3D) NbO network. After 2-fold interpenetration, there still remains 1D channels runing along the c-axis, with alternating large cages and small necks (Figure ). The diameters of cage and neck in 1 are about 9.2 and 5.7 Å, respectively, taking into account the van der Waals radii. By incorporation of a methyl group in 2, cage and neck diameters are reduced to ca. 7.7 and 5.2 Å, respectively. The total solvent-accessible volumes are correspondingly reduced from 26.5% in 1 to 21.6% in 2. The pore size differences suggest that 1 would have larger saturation adsorption capacity but lower adsorption enthalpy than 2.
elements.clean_text: The isostructural compounds crystallize in the trigonal space group R3̅. Each octahedrally coordinated CoII ion is chelated by the 2-pyridyl and triazolate 2-nitrogens from two ligands in the trans configuration, and the two remaining coordination sites are occupied by 4-pyridyl nitrogens from adjacent units (Figure S1, ), giving rise to a 4-connected three-dimensional (3D) NbO network. After 2-fold interpenetration, there still remains 1D channels runing along the c-axis, with alternating large cages and small necks (Figure ). The diameters of cage and neck in 1 are about 9.2 and 5.7 Å, respectively, taking into account the van der Waals radii. By incorporation of a methyl group in 2, cage and neck diameters are reduced to ca. 7.7 and 5.2 Å, respectively. The total solvent-accessible volumes are correspondingly reduced from 26.5% in 1 to 21.6% in 2. The pore size differences suggest that 1 would have larger saturation adsorption capacity but lower adsorption enthalpy than 2.

elements.content: (a) Two-fold interpenetrating NbO net, (b) side-view of the 1D channel, and perspective views of the framework structures of (c) 1 and (d) 2 along the c-axes (the 3′-hydrogen atoms and -methyl groups on 2-pyridyl groups are highlighted in space filling modes).
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Two-fold interpenetrating NbO net, (b) side-view of the 1D channel, and perspective views of the framework structures of (c) 1 and (d) 2 along the c-axes (the 3'-hydrogen atoms and -methyl groups on 2-pyridyl groups are highlighted in space filling modes).

elements.content: The triazolate 1- and 4-nitrogens in 1 and 2 are uncoordinated. While the 4-nitrogens are completely covered by adjacent framework components, the 1-nitrogens are partially exposed on the pore surfaces. Due to the blockage of methyl group, the triazolate 1-nitrogens in 2 are much less exposed than those in 1 (Figure S2, ). However, these partially exposed nitrogens may not be able to modulate the sorption properties, as their lone electron pairs do not point into the channels. Indeed, the solvent molecules in the two crystal structures are highly disordered, giving no specific information about host−guest interactions.
elements.clean_text: The triazolate 1- and 4-nitrogens in 1 and 2 are uncoordinated. While the 4-nitrogens are completely covered by adjacent framework components, the 1-nitrogens are partially exposed on the pore surfaces. Due to the blockage of methyl group, the triazolate 1-nitrogens in 2 are much less exposed than those in 1 (Figure S2, ). However, these partially exposed nitrogens may not be able to modulate the sorption properties, as their lone electron pairs do not point into the channels. Indeed, the solvent molecules in the two crystal structures are highly disordered, giving no specific information about host-guest interactions.

elements.content: Thermogravimetry analysis and variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction show that 1 and 2 can be readily activated, keeping the host framworsks unchanged up to 440 °C in N2 and 370 °C in air, respectively (Figures S3, S4, and S5, ), which are high values for PCPs.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetry analysis and variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction show that 1 and 2 can be readily activated, keeping the host framworsks unchanged up to 440 °C in N2 and 370 °C in air, respectively (Figures S3, S4, and S5, ), which are high values for PCPs.

elements.content: N2 adsorption isotherms of activated 1 and 2 are measured at 77 K (Figure a). It shows type I isotherm with an apparent Langmuir surface area of 511 m2 g−1 for 1. The adsorption amount of N2 at saturation is about 120 cm3(STP) g−1, which corresponds to 8.1 N2 per cage. In contrast, 2 only exhibits particle surface adsorption (5.7 cm3(STP) g−1 or 0.3 N2 per cage at 1 atm), which may be derived from framework contraction or diffusion problem at low temperature since the aperture size of 2 is larger than the kinetic diameter of N2 (3.64 Å).
elements.clean_text: N2 adsorption isotherms of activated 1 and 2 are measured at 77 K (Figure a). It shows type I isotherm with an apparent Langmuir surface area of 511 m2g-1 for 1. The adsorption amount of N2 at saturation is about 120 cm3(STP) g-1, which corresponds to 8.1 N2 per cage. In contrast, 2 only exhibits particle surface adsorption (5.7 cm3(STP) g-1 or 0.3 N2 per cage at 1 atm), which may be derived from framework contraction or diffusion problem at low temperature since the aperture size of 2 is larger than the kinetic diameter of N2 (3.64 Å).

elements.content: (a) Adsorption isotherms of N2 and H2 measured at 77 K and CO2 measured at 195 K, and (b) the adsorption enthalpies of H2 and CO2.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Adsorption isotherms of N2 and H2 measured at 77 K and CO2 measured at 195 K, and (b) the adsorption enthalpies of H2 and CO2.

elements.content: The H2 uptake at 77 K and 1 atm for 1 and 2 are ca. 75 and 46 cm3(STP) g−1, respectively (Figure a). This significant difference in H2 sorption capacity can be attributed to the void volume of 1 and 2. Virial analysis of the H2 adsorption isotherms measured at 77 and 87 K (Figures b, S6 and S7, ) revealed that the adsorption enthalpy of 1 at zero surface coverage is 9.2(1) kJ mol−1, which is higher than most PCPs with large pores. However, the most intriguing result is that 2, even though it has a smaller pore size, gives substantially lower adsorption enthalpies. The H2 adsorption enthalpy for 2 at zero surface coverage is 6.0(2) kJ mol−1. To our knowledge, this is very unusual compared to previous reports, where smaller pores result in stronger overlapping potentials and thus higher adsorption energy.
elements.clean_text: The H2 uptake at 77 K and 1 atm for 1 and 2 are ca. 75 and 46 cm3(STP)g-1, respectively (Figure a). This significant difference in H2 sorption capacity can be attributed to the void volume of 1 and 2. Virial analysis of the H2 adsorption isotherms measured at 77 and 87 K (Figures b, S6 and S7, ) revealed that the adsorption enthalpy of 1 at zero surface coverage is 9.2(1) kJ mol-1, which is higher than most PCPs with large pores. However, the most intriguing result is that 2, even though it has a smaller pore size, gives substantially lower adsorption enthalpies. The H2 adsorption enthalpy for 2 at zero surface coverage is 6.0(2) kJmol-1. To our knowledge, this is very unusual compared to previous reports, where smaller pores result in stronger overlapping potentials and thus higher adsorption energy.

elements.content: In order to confirm the unusual gas attraction effect and sample quality after activation, CO2 sorptions were measured for 1 and 2 (Figure a) at 195 K, both of which exhibit type I isotherm with an apparent Langmuir surface area of 683 and 499 m2 g−1, respectively. The saturation adsorption amount for 1 is about 117 cm3(STP) g−1, corresponding to 7.9 CO2 per cage; while the saturation adsorption amount for 2 is about 84 cm3(STP) g−1 and corresponds to 6.0 CO2 per cage. The densities of CO2 in the channels of 1 and 2 at saturation are about 1.0 and 0.94 g cm−3, respectively, which are close to the density of liquid CO2 (1.10 g cm3), showing that the channels are effectively filled by CO2 molecules.
elements.clean_text: In order to confirm the unusual gas attraction effect and sample quality after activation, CO2 sorptions were measured for 1 and 2 (Figure a) at 195 K, both of which exhibit type I isotherm with an apparent Langmuir surface area of 683 and 499 m2g-1, respectively. The saturation adsorption amount for 1 is about 117 cm3(STP)g-1, corresponding to 7.9 CO2 per cage; while the saturation adsorption amount for 2 is about 84 cm3(STP)g-1 and corresponds to 6.0 CO2 per cage. The densities of CO2 in the channels of 1 and 2 at saturation are about 1.0 and 0.94 gcm-3, respectively, which are close to the density of liquid CO2 (1.10 gcm3), showing that the channels are effectively filled by CO2 molecules.

elements.content: Furthermore, CO2 sorptions were performed at near room temperature, which would give more reliable results connected to crystal structures determined at room termperature. Virial analyses of the CO2 adsorption isotherms measured at 273 and 283 K (Figures b, S8 and S9, ) also illustrate stronger binding ability for 1. The enthalpies at zero coverage of 1 and 2 are 26.3(5) and 23.3(7) kJ mol−1, respectively. These observations confirm that the isostructural framework 1 with larger pore size and total pore volume shows larger sorption amounts and higher enthalpies for both H2 and CO2, which are very unusual and have been only observed for H2 adsorption in Li+-doped PCP. As discussed above, the unusual sorption behaviors can be only derived from the subtle difference on the exposure degree of uncoordinated nitrogens. In other words, even partially exposed uncoordinated nitrogens in 1 can lead to obvious improvement of adsorption enthapy (>3 kJ mol−1).
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, CO2 sorptions were performed at near room temperature, which would give more reliable results connected to crystal structures determined at room termperature. Virial analyses of the CO2 adsorption isotherms measured at 273 and 283 K (Figures b, S8 and S9, ) also illustrate stronger binding ability for 1. The enthalpies at zero coverage of 1 and 2 are 26.3(5) and 23.3(7) kJmol-1, respectively. These observations confirm that the isostructural framework 1 with larger pore size and total pore volume shows larger sorption amounts and higher enthalpies for both H2 and CO2, which are very unusual and have been only observed for H2 adsorption in Li+-doped PCP. As discussed above, the unusual sorption behaviors can be only derived from the subtle difference on the exposure degree of uncoordinated nitrogens. In other words, even partially exposed uncoordinated nitrogens in 1 can lead to obvious improvement of adsorption enthapy (>3 kJmol-1).

elements.content: Due to the samples’ poor single-crystallinity after removing guest molecules, we can not obtain the gas-loaded crystal strucutres. To further confirm the adsorption mechanism, grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations were employed to investigate the interactions between CO2 molecules and desolvated 1 and 2. Simulations were performed for a model that includes electrostatic and Lennard−Jones 6−12 potential among the atoms in the system. The framework and the individual CO2 molecules were considered to be rigid. Interactions between CO2 molecules and framework were modeled with the UFF force fields (see the ).
elements.clean_text: Due to the samples' poor single-crystallinity after removing guest molecules, we can not obtain the gas-loaded crystal strucutres. To further confirm the adsorption mechanism, grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations were employed to investigate the interactions between CO2 molecules and desolvated 1 and 2. Simulations were performed for a model that includes electrostatic and Lennard-Jones 6-12 potential among the atoms in the system. The framework and the individual CO2 molecules were considered to be rigid. Interactions between CO2 molecules and framework were modeled with the UFF force fields (see the ).

elements.content: CO2 binding sites and corresponding enthalpies were obtained from the simulations. The calculations show that 1 possesses larger adsorption enthalpies than does 2, which is in agreement with the experimental observations. The adsorption enthalpies at zero coverage are calculated to be 26.3 and 24.8 kJ mol−1 in 1 and 2, respectively. More interestingly, the preferential binding sites of the two structures are very different (Table S2, ). In 1, the CO2 molecule locates inside the large cage rather than the small aperture (Figure a), indicating that there is stronger binding interaction than the overlapping potentials. The CO2 molecule forms short contacts with the uncoordinated triazolate 1-nitrogen by its electropositive carbon (C···N = 3.57 Å, O···N = 3.76 and 3.77 Å). The C···N distance, being slightly larger than the sum of van der Waals radii of carbon (1.70 Å) and nitrogen (1.55 Å), suggests attractive interaction, presumably electrostatic in nature. The partially exposed nitrogen serves as an electronegative site. In 2, the CO2 molecule is embedded in the small neck as expected (Figure b), which has strong overlapping potentials. CO2 is not likely interacting with the uncoordianted nitrogens as judged from the long C···N separation (C···N = 6.59 Å, O···N = 5.84 and 7.46 Å), but forms short contacts with the 2-pyridyl carbons (shortest C···C = 3.43 Å). Further checking of other possible sorption sites verified that the CO2 molecule can not be located close to the uncoordinated triazolate 1-nitrogen, which should be ascribed to the blockage effect of methyl group (Figure S11, ). Therefore, it is reasonable to conclude that the partially exposed uncoordinated nitrogen in 1 is able to provide a nondissociative interaction with gas molecules.
elements.clean_text: CO2 binding sites and corresponding enthalpies were obtained from the simulations. The calculations show that 1 possesses larger adsorption enthalpies than does 2, which is in agreement with the experimental observations. The adsorption enthalpies at zero coverage are calculated to be 26.3 and 24.8 kJmol-1 in 1 and 2, respectively. More interestingly, the preferential binding sites of the two structures are very different (Table S2, ). In 1, the CO2 molecule locates inside the large cage rather than the small aperture (Figure a), indicating that there is stronger binding interaction than the overlapping potentials. The CO2 molecule forms short contacts with the uncoordinated triazolate 1-nitrogen by its electropositive carbon (C⋅⋅⋅N = 3.57 Å, O⋅⋅⋅N = 3.76 and 3.77 Å). The C⋅⋅⋅N distance, being slightly larger than the sum of van der Waals radii of carbon (1.70 Å) and nitrogen (1.55 Å), suggests attractive interaction, presumably electrostatic in nature. The partially exposed nitrogen serves as an electronegative site. In 2, the CO2 molecule is embedded in the small neck as expected (Figure b), which has strong overlapping potentials. CO2 is not likely interacting with the uncoordianted nitrogens as judged from the long C⋅⋅⋅N separation (C⋅⋅⋅N = 6.59 Å, O⋅⋅⋅N = 5.84 and 7.46 Å), but forms short contacts with the 2-pyridyl carbons (shortest C⋅⋅⋅C = 3.43 Å). Further checking of other possible sorption sites verified that the CO2 molecule can not be located close to the uncoordinated triazolate 1-nitrogen, which should be ascribed to the blockage effect of methyl group (Figure S11, ). Therefore, it is reasonable to conclude that the partially exposed uncoordinated nitrogen in 1 is able to provide a nondissociative interaction with gas molecules.

elements.content: Preferential CO2 locations in (a) 1 and (b) 2 obtained from GCMC calculations (the 3′-hydrogen atoms and -methyl groups on 2-pyridyl groups are highlighted in green).
elements.clean_text: 3  Preferential CO2 locations in (a) 1 and (b) 2 obtained from GCMC calculations (the 3'-hydrogen atoms and -methyl groups on 2-pyridyl groups are highlighted in green).

elements.content: In summary, we have designed and synthesized two isomorphous PCPs with highly related pore characteristics, which represents an ideal system to investigate the effect of nonclassic active site for gas adsorption. Our results demonstrated that even partially exposed uncoordinated nitrogens can effectively enhance the gas binding affinity, which may has significant implication for future studies for engineering of new porous materials.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have designed and synthesized two isomorphous PCPs with highly related pore characteristics, which represents an ideal system to investigate the effect of nonclassic active site for gas adsorption. Our results demonstrated that even partially exposed uncoordinated nitrogens can effectively enhance the gas binding affinity, which may has significant implication for future studies for engineering of new porous materials.

elements.content:
Crystallographic data, synthesis, EA, PXRD, additional structural plots, and additional sorption data. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

References
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic data, synthesis, EA, PXRD, additional structural plots, and additional sorption data. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

References

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetry analysis and variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction show that 1 and 2 can be readily activated, keeping the host framworsks unchanged up to 440 °C in N2 and 370 °C in air, respectively (Figures S3, S4, and S5, ), which are high values for PCPs.

N2 adsorption isotherms of activated 1 and 2 are measured at 77 K (Figure a). It shows type I isotherm with an apparent Langmuir surface area of 511 m2 g−1 for 1. The adsorption amount of N2 at saturation is about 120 cm3(STP) g−1, which corresponds to 8.1 N2 per cage. In contrast, 2 only exhibits particle surface adsorption (5.7 cm3(STP) g−1 or 0.3 N2 per cage at 1 atm), which may be derived from framework contraction or diffusion problem at low temperature since the aperture size of 2 is larger than the kinetic diameter of N2 (3.64 Å).

The H2 uptake at 77 K and 1 atm for 1 and 2 are ca. 75 and 46 cm3(STP) g−1, respectively (Figure a). This significant difference in H2 sorption capacity can be attributed to the void volume of 1 and 2. Virial analysis of the H2 adsorption isotherms measured at 77 and 87 K (Figures b, S6 and S7, ) revealed that the adsorption enthalpy of 1 at zero surface coverage is 9.2(1) kJ mol−1, which is higher than most PCPs with large pores. However, the most intriguing result is that 2, even though it has a smaller pore size, gives substantially lower adsorption enthalpies. The H2 adsorption enthalpy for 2 at zero surface coverage is 6.0(2) kJ mol−1. To our knowledge, this is very unusual compared to previous reports, where smaller pores result in stronger overlapping potentials and thus higher adsorption energy.

In order to confirm the unusual gas attraction effect and sample quality after activation, CO2 sorptions were measured for 1 and 2 (Figure a) at 195 K, both of which exhibit type I isotherm with an apparent Langmuir surface area of 683 and 499 m2 g−1, respectively. The saturation adsorption amount for 1 is about 117 cm3(STP) g−1, corresponding to 7.9 CO2 per cage; while the saturation adsorption amount for 2 is about 84 cm3(STP) g−1 and corresponds to 6.0 CO2 per cage. The densities of CO2 in the channels of 1 and 2 at saturation are about 1.0 and 0.94 g cm−3, respectively, which are close to the density of liquid CO2 (1.10 g cm3), showing that the channels are effectively filled by CO2 molecules.

Thermogravimetry analysis and variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction show that 1 and 2 can be readily activated, keeping the host framworsks unchanged up to 440 °C in N2 and 370 °C in air, respectively (Figures S3, S4, and S5, ), which are high values for PCPs. 

N2 adsorption isotherms of activated 1 and 2 are measured at 77 K (Figure a). It shows type I isotherm with an apparent Langmuir surface area of 511 m2g-1 for 1. The adsorption amount of N2 at saturation is about 120 cm3(STP) g-1, which corresponds to 8.1 N2 per cage. In contrast, 2 only exhibits particle surface adsorption (5.7 cm3(STP) g-1 or 0.3 N2 per cage at 1 atm), which may be derived from framework contraction or diffusion problem at low temperature since the aperture size of 2 is larger than the kinetic diameter of N2 (3.64 Å).

The H2 uptake at 77 K and 1 atm for 1 and 2 are ca. 75 and 46 cm3(STP)g-1, respectively (Figure a). This significant difference in H2 sorption capacity can be attributed to the void volume of 1 and 2. Virial analysis of the H2 adsorption isotherms measured at 77 and 87 K (Figures b, S6 and S7, ) revealed that the adsorption enthalpy of 1 at zero surface coverage is 9.2(1) kJ mol-1, which is higher than most PCPs with large pores. However, the most intriguing result is that 2, even though it has a smaller pore size, gives substantially lower adsorption enthalpies. The H2 adsorption enthalpy for 2 at zero surface coverage is 6.0(2) kJmol-1. To our knowledge, this is very unusual compared to previous reports, where smaller pores result in stronger overlapping potentials and thus higher adsorption energy. 

In order to confirm the unusual gas attraction effect and sample quality after activation, CO2 sorptions were measured for 1 and 2 (Figure a) at 195 K, both of which exhibit type I isotherm with an apparent Langmuir surface area of 683 and 499 m2g-1, respectively. The saturation adsorption amount for 1 is about 117 cm3(STP)g-1, corresponding to 7.9 CO2 per cage; while the saturation adsorption amount for 2 is about 84 cm3(STP)g-1 and corresponds to 6.0 CO2 per cage. The densities of CO2 in the channels of 1 and 2 at saturation are about 1.0 and 0.94 gcm-3, respectively, which are close to the density of liquid CO2 (1.10 gcm3), showing that the channels are effectively filled by CO2 molecules.

metadata.title: Nonclassical Active Site for Enhanced Gas Sorption in Porous Coordination Polymer
